article.title: Anisotropies of the magnetic field fluctuations at kinetic scales in the solar wind : Cluster observations

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the general relationship between the beta factors βe and βp in the observed solar wind data?
choices: βe is always larger than βp.
βe is always smaller than βp.
βe and βp are not correlated.
βe and βp are equal.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the general trend observed between the solar wind speed (Vsw) and the electron to proton temperature ratio (Te/Tp)?
choices: Te/Tp increases with increasing Vsw.
Te/Tp decreases with increasing Vsw.
Te/Tp is not correlated with Vsw.
Te/Tp remains constant across all values of Vsw.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the observed range of the anisotropy ratio Tp⊥/Tp|| for the proton temperature?
choices: Tp⊥/Tp||  is always greater than 1.
Tp⊥/Tp||  is always smaller than 1.
Tp⊥/Tp||  fluctuates around 1.
No specific trend is observed for  Tp⊥/Tp||.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded about the anisotropy ratio Te⊥/Te|| for the electron temperature?
choices: Te⊥/Te||  is always greater than 1.
Te⊥/Te|| is always smaller than 1.
Te⊥/Te|| fluctuates around 1.
Te⊥/Te||  shows a clear decreasing trend with increasing βe.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the relative intensities of Pyy, Pxx, and Pzz spectra at frequencies above the proton cyclotron frequency (fcp)?
choices: The fluctuations are isotropic at all frequencies.
Pyy (perpendicular to both Bo and R) is generally the most intense, indicating anisotropy.
Pzz (compressive fluctuations) consistently dominates over the transverse components.
Pxx (perpendicular to Bo in the plane (R, Bo)) shows no significant difference in intensity compared to Pyy and Pzz.
